{include "affiliate_loader"} Call on elected officials to dramatically reduce our state's prison population. {include "pre-header-spacing"}{beacon}

{include "default_salutation"} –

During the COVID-19 pandemic, a jail or prison sentence can quickly turn into a death sentence. Social distancing is impossible for people who are imprisoned. As experts and survivors have repeatedly warned: incarceration makes it impossible to take adequate protective steps against a deadly virus. Without swift action, the consequences will be catastrophic.

People in prisons are terrified, and their loved ones reach out every day to let us know how difficult and cruel it is to be confined in the midst of a pandemic.

We're inviting you to hear their stories in their own words this week. The ACLU of New Jersey is co-hosting a virtual town hall this Thursday, May 14, at 10 a.m. to join survivors, advocates, and faith leaders in demanding further action from our elected officials.

VIRTUAL TOWN HALL

Join us to demand further action and hold our elected officials accountable in a virtual town hall with survivors, advocates, faith leaders, and loved ones of people who are trapped in New Jersey's prisons in the midst of a public health nightmare.

Thursday, May 14, 10 a.m.
Hosted on Zoom

Please note: This link will take you to a third-party website, zoom.us
Register


We'll have six people sharing their stories – loved ones of people currently in prison and loved ones of people who died of COVID-19 while incarcerated – sharing why it's so urgent that prisons drastically reduce their population.

Although Governor Murphy signed an executive order a month ago to temporarily release over 1,000 eligible people from prison, only 83 have been released. In New Jersey, 42 people have died in state custody due to COVID-19. It's clear that our leaders are failing to heed experts' warnings and aren't responding to the lived experiences of those who are incarcerated.

Join us to demand further action and hold our elected officials accountable this Thursday, May 14, at 10 a.m.

Sarah Fajardo
Policy Director, ACLU of {affiliate_name}
